Literature Review: The role of long-chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), specifically eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in cardiovascular health has been extensively studied. These fatty acids, predominantly found in seafood, supplements, and pharmaceutical preparations, have been associated with a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in numerous prospective cohort studies. The cardioprotective effects of EPA and DHA are attributed to their ability to modulate several risk factors for CVD, including lipid profiles, blood pressure, inflammation, and endothelial function (Mozaffarian & Wu, 2011). However, the evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and meta-analyses presents a more nuanced picture, with some studies supporting the use of EPA and DHA for cardiovascular protection, particularly in high-risk populations, while others show minimal or no benefit (Rizos et al., 2012). This literature review aims to synthesize the current understanding of the pros and cons of long-chain omega-3 PUFAs in cardiovascular health, focusing on their role in both primary and secondary prevention of CVD, potential mechanisms of action, and the implications of recent RCTs and meta-analyses. Additionally, potential adverse effects associated with the consumption of these fatty acids will be discussed. The beneficial effects of EPA and DHA on cardiovascular health are thought to be mediated through several mechanisms. These include the reduction of triglyceride levels, anti-inflammatory effects, antiarrhythmic properties, and improvements in endothelial function (Calder, 2012). EPA and DHA have been shown to lower triglyceride levels by reducing the synthesis of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) particles in the liver and enhancing their clearance from the bloodstream (Harris et al., 2008). Their anti-inflammatory effects are mediated through the production of specialized pro-resolving mediators (SPMs) that actively resolve inflammation and promote tissue repair (Serhan et al., 2008). Furthermore, EPA and DHA can modulate the electrical properties of cardiac cells, reducing the risk of arrhythmias, and improve endothelial function by increasing the availability of nitric oxide, a potent vasodilator (Mozaffarian & Wu, 2011). Despite these potential benefits, the results from RCTs and meta-analyses have been mixed. Some large trials, such as the GISSI-Prevenzione trial, have demonstrated a significant reduction in cardiovascular mortality and sudden cardiac death with the use of omega-3 supplements in patients with a history of myocardial infarction (Marchioli et al., 2002). Similarly, the REDUCE-IT trial showed that high-dose EPA significantly reduced the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events in high-risk patients with elevated triglycerides (Bhatt et al., 2019). However, other studies, including the VITAL trial, found no significant benefit of omega-3 supplementation in the primary prevention of major cardiovascular events among a general population (Manson et al., 2019). These discrepancies may be due to differences in study populations, dosages, and formulations of omega-3 supplements, as well as the background diet of participants. In addition to their potential benefits, there are also concerns regarding the adverse effects of long-chain omega-3 PUFAs. High doses of EPA and DHA have been associated with an increased risk of bleeding, particularly in individuals taking anticoagulant medications (Bays, 2007). There is also some evidence suggesting that high levels of omega-3 fatty acids may impair immune function and increase the risk of infections (Calder, 2013). Furthermore, the environmental impact of sourcing omega-3 fatty acids from fish oil has raised concerns about sustainability and the potential for contamination with environmental pollutants (Tacon & Metian, 2013). In conclusion, while long-chain omega-3 PUFAs, particularly EPA and DHA, have demonstrated potential benefits in reducing the risk of CVD through various mechanisms, the evidence from RCTs and meta-analyses is inconsistent. The use of omega-3 supplements may be beneficial in specific high-risk populations, but their role in the general population remains uncertain. Additionally, potential adverse effects and environmental concerns should be considered when recommending omega-3 supplementation. Further research is needed to clarify the optimal dosage, formulation, and target populations for omega-3 supplementation in the prevention and management of CVD.
